reviews.text: SO MUCH FUN! My 1 y/o and 5 y/o loved everything each area of the museum had to offer. All exhibits were hands on and enjoyed by kids and adults.  Each area of the museum engages kids curiosity; allowing them to explore science first hand and still have so much fun doing it. My girls loved playing with the bubbles/ water table river (ish) [bring change of clothes], construction room and so much more! Pack food and eat at a table by the waterfront  too.

The $1 Friday after 5 deal is great. Don’t think it would be worth regular admission though. There is a decent amount for the kids to do but doesn’t hold up to the fun my kids have had at other children’s museums in the country. It only took us 2 hours to pretty much see everything and be tired of this place. Glad we got in on the good deal on a Friday and didn’t waste money.

The Children's Museum is a great way to spend a day with the children and to expand their imaginations!!!! 
There are three floors full of hands on fun and opportunities for all ages to expand their minds. On the bottom floor, there is a section where  children can experience the effects of gravity, see how simple machines can work, and generate energy through generators.
I have children ages 4, 7, and 13. I went with family who had children ages 1, 3, 8 and 10.....they ALL had a blast and we spent 3 hours there.

My nephews love this place. I loved the bubble room. So many great interactive games and activities. Perfect for cold days. I visited this time just to pop into the gift shop and smash some souvenir pennies.

We went as a family for the $1 admission after 5 on Fridays. It was great! Our 2 year old really enjoyed the "play place" on the second floor, which had a peaceful environment. He of course also loved around the other exhibits. Highly recommend.

I have been wanting to go inside for a long time and got my chance today! There are a lot of historical, unique, interesting, and really  incredible scientific tools on display. It was great to see the beginnings of some amazing advances in the science field.

A great place to visit while you're in the Harvard or cambridge area. It's one of the few places that allow you to enter for free. It's not big probably the size of 2 classrooms but its packed with interesting instruments that have defined the knowledge we now take for granted. A great place to visit while you're in the Harvard or cambridge area. It's one of the few places that allow you to enter for free. It's not big probably the size of 2 classrooms but its packed with interesting instruments that have defined the knowledge we now take for granted.

A great place to visit while you're in the Harvard or cambridge area. It's one of the few places that allow you to enter for free. It's not big probably the size of 2 classrooms but its packed with interesting instruments that have defined the knowledge we now take for granted.

We've come a long way. The Collection of Scientific and Medical Instruments is compact, but still provides a stunning visual foundation for how far we've come in our ability to see within ourselves and to see out to the stars. There are examples of early telescopes and microscopes. There is old-time auditory testing equipment side by side with electric lighting from another era. The exhibit features a Grandfather-type clock that was used to sync time over telegraph wires before it was possible anywhere else. Don't overlook the early Dr. Frankenstein MRI machine. Not a great place for chronologically young children, but wonderful for the wondering child in the rest of us.
An amazing place for science- minded  kids and adults alike. A must see when visiting Harvard.

So this museum is pretty huge, way bigger than I had expected because of the multiple levels. They have a wide variety of art do you should definitely be able to find something that you like. The weird thing about this place was that you could get coffee right by the entrance to one of the rooms, but still inside the building, and there are no signs saying that you should not take the drinks into the gallery. So my wife and I were yelled at after a few minutes of being in the gallery. In hindsight it should have been fairly obvious that it's not allowed, but I would definitely suggest signs, especially because of the close proximity of the coffee area to one of the rooms in the gallery.

Excellent collection located at one of the world's foremost institutions. Comfortable place to work and study, unique selection of artifacts from throughout their archives - including a rare selection of pigments. A bit small in scope, however, relative to the university's collections.

Excellent collection located at one of the world's foremost institutions. Comfortable place to work and study, unique selection of artifacts from throughout their archives - including a rare selection of pigments. A bit small in scope, however, relative to the university's collections.

After 10 years of planning and 6 years of construction, the Harvard Art Museum was finally reopened in the late fall of 2014. The two-storey exhibition hall, which cost $350 million, brings together all the treasures of the previous three museums. Designed by Renzo Piano, the new pavilion moves the original Art Research Center from the first floor to the top floor, and is equipped with new art restoration and maintenance equipment. The Art Research Center, which is open to visitors, is a major feature of the Harvard Art Museum. Visitors can enjoy some precious original works and have a close look at the experience.

Went to two Erasmus lectures in the auditorium -- a great place to look and listen but not so much for note-taking if you're so inclined. Seats are comfy and legroom ample -- they often screen films here. Parking is free in the Broadway Garage (off Felton St.) when the museum hosts special events!

An amazing adventure for adults and kids. World-class taxidermy. Awesome mineral collection. Incredible fossils. Informative rotating exhibits. Friendly and helpful staff. It's easy to forget that the glass flowers are made out of glass. I've been there 10 or more times and still don't feel like I've seen everything.

I loved it! There's so much to see. Me and my kids agree this was more enjoyable than the Boston Museum of science. It's compact so we got to see a lot without walking a marathon. The dinosaurs were stunning too!

One of the best collections the humanity has stored. An astonishing travel to the past of the history and the past of your childhood.

The museum is divided into two parts, left and right arms. In order to have enough time you will need one hour for any of them.

I stopped here by chance on my way through Boston. It is truly a well put together and fascinating place! They have an extensive collection of artifacts, taxidermy animals, insects, plants, fossils and more! It was well worth the time and money spent!

Lots of great exhibits. Definitely worth spending half a day (or maybe even a whole day) here taking everything in! Don't expect a museum like the Museum of Natural History or the Field Museum - this museum feels more approachable and familiar which results in a more engaging and interactive feeling.

Can't say enough about this fabulous museum!  Kudos to Isabella for creating such a warm and lovely spot for all of her art treasures. You can easily use your mobile as an audio guide - definitely take advantage of it as you learn so much of the history of Mrs. Gardner and many works of art. Be prepared to spend hours enjoying all three floors. The conservatory in the middle is gorgeous!

What gem in the middle of this beautiful city!  I loved every inch and cannot wait to visit again!  We discovered this museum from a hop on/off city bus tour and I am so grateful!  What an interesting American woman!  And the guardians of this museum do an excellent job!  It’s a beautiful place to spend the day!  You’ll be transported back in time.  Don’t miss out!

My partner and I went here for the 10$ tickets and art making studio and stayed because it super awesome! The art is wonky and strewn about, the garden is beautiful, and the food at the restaurant is delicious. We spent close to 4 hours here and it was a great experience. I definitely recommend!

Beautiful museum. Each room is an immersive experience into another era. Courtyard is a beautiful highlight, with a rotating selection of plants and flowers. Student tickets-$10. Guided tours are free (see the board) but you'll have to book a place on the tour,at the main reception. There is also a free audio guide available on the website, which takes you through each room and points out the highlights. lockers available for free. Don't miss the resident canary in the Living Room!

This was an impressive and homely museum. Getting to know Isabella's life and personality through her garden and collection was a great experience. Picking out the portraits of her from her collection was fun as I didn't know what she looked like going in, I felt like I was unraveling her life. Plus the central atrium garden was beautiful!

It would be awesome to be able to attend some party or event in the garden, truly a great building and museum.

I was especially struck by the correspondences between her and extremely famous people of her time, US presidents, some of the most famous composers, artists and writers, wow!!

That is MIT Museum it a rare place with days of activities and exhibits to explore and learn. I would recommend taking two visits to take in all the extraordinary historical finds and nature. The science of the earth is amazing to see all the theories. A family could spend all day here . So maybe come early, take a break for a meal and then explore the rest of the place or just plan two visits to be able to enjoy each educational exhibit fully. Most of the exhibits are interactive and fun for all ages.

Mind blowing collection of scientifically, technological, art stuff.

Generally takes 2-3 hours to absorb the place completely. If I remember it right, entry is 50% discounted for folks in college right now, for general crowd it is $10

Sharing a few videos to give a taste of gestural engineering projects shared on first floor during Aug 2018

MIT Museum it a rare place with days of activities and exhibits to explore and learn. I would recommend taking two visits to take in all the extraordinary historical finds and nature. The science of the earth is amazing to see all the theories. A family could spend all day here . So maybe come early, take a break for a meal and then explore the rest of the place or just plan two visits to be able to enjoy each educational exhibit fully. Most of the exhibits are interactive and fun for all ages.

It was a cool place. The exhibits could have been better or more interesting but it was a cool experience. No food or drinks allowed, so don't bring your coffee unless you want to leave it at the front desk

Very enjoyed the museum! Despite the name, it’s not really though an MIT Museum (it has little of MIT’s history per se), but more like a museum of technology that came out of it. It’s a great spot to come alone (it’s not so large) or with friends and family, and there are some interactive activities that children can also participate (at specific hours).

We booked the community room in the Black History Museum for a brunch reception the day before our wedding. It proved the perfect backdrop to welcome family and friends to our weekend celebration, and to introduce our out-of-town guests to the rich history and culture of black Richmond. Heather Anderson and her team were incredibly accommodating and hospitable. She was a dream to work with throughout the planning process, and even served as a greeter, personally welcoming every attendee at the entrance of the museum. We were completely blown away by the warmth, kindness, and generosity shown to us by the staff during our reception, and we look forward to hosting our next event at this venue in the near future. It’s a true gem of Richmond, and a Virginian treasure!
Our tour guide was very knowledgeable and passionate about the history and relevance of the museum. Had a great time well worth an couple hours of your time
Our Alighieri Montessori school attended their program and it was amazing!  We learned so much.  Great staff!

Comfortable museum detailing the work and life of Frederick Douglas. Highly recommend the tour for unknown facts of the African American experience in Boston and the beginnings of Beacon Hill. Staff is very friendly and the gift shop has eye-catching curiosities.
This was a pleasant experience. It was kind of out of the way, up a hill, and I was confused getting there, but after that it was pleasant.

The New England Aquarium was fantastic!!!! Loved the seal feedings and all the exhibits. Wish there was more! The training sessions were great and short enough for my young kids to stay engaged. Next time, I'm definitely going to make sure we make enough time to go to the Shark and Ray touching area. It looked so cool, but we had to be on our way.

Big fish, small fish, sharks, penguins, eels, sting rays, and much more. It's been awhile since I have been to an aquarium, but this one seemed pretty good. The penguin exhibit is right by the entrance. You could see them get fed which was cool. There is a huge tank right in the center with all different types of sea creatures. The walkway wraps around the tank which is a good setup. There are 3 or 4 floors, so plenty to see here. Even got to see piranhas close up. I saw the movie piranhas recently, but these piranhas didn't seem quite as vicious. Nevertheless, I wouldn't want to get in a close encounter with them. 

I suggest buying tickets online so you don't need to wait on the line outside. It gets quite crowded during the summer weekends as one would expect. Fun place for all ages.

The experience was awesome. They have a wide variety of sea animals. They have beautiful color fishes of every sizes as seen on TV shows. It was a great experience to see those marine animals in front of you. They have small tanks where in presence of authorities you can touch the sting rays, starfish and some variety of shark. The seals are a fun to see and they play amongst themselves. The penguins swim, play, chase each other and dive. Overall, it is a must watch attraction.

The aquarium is one of my favorite places to go to in Boston. The staff is excellent, and they are always making changes and improvements to exhibits. The cost of a membership pays for itself if you live in the area.

We love this place so much that it is where I proposed to my wife and where we ultimately decided to get married. As an event venue it is unmatched. The transformation was astounding and the staff made sure that every little detail was perfect.

The New England Aquarium has been a place that draws many visitors near and far and has been a staple in Boston for years. It's really cool being the parent and taking my little one just like my parents did for me many years ago. My little one lived touching the rays, starfish and crabs. The Giant Ocean Tank still amazes me with the variety one sea life. And it very cool seeing the many different exhibits from penguins and sea Lions to pond life and sea dragons. You will have a blast for sure!

This place, including the adjacent natural history museum, is one of the best museums in the country. The 5 hours we spent were not nearly enough! There is so much to learn and see, and the collection is presented so beautifully that you actually want to spend time reading it all. I kept wishing that I lived in Boston, just so I could go there every week and take the time to really absorb everything and appreciate what Harvard has done here. Expect random school children groups to come through (who don't understand what they have and we don't 🙁) and distract you.
Many fantastic exhibits and historical accounts. Great range of artifacts on display accurately recounting the cultures of yesteryear.

This museum was one of my favorite places during our Boston vacation. The museum has many great things to see. We got there an hour before closing but we managed to see everything and enjoy them. If you're close by give it a try. Highly recommended.
Great little cultural museum connected with the Harvard Museum of Natural History (entrance to one is good for the other). Free to Massachusetts residents with ID Sundays before noon.

Expected a huge collection, but so far whatever is located is quite unique but dims in front of the Museum of Fine arts collection. This is definitely a recommended museum for all the collection and educative information the exhibits carry.

My daughter and had the privilege of getting a private tour of this magnificent ship by Peter Robbins yesterday.   Proud to be a part the US Navy - Peter is one of the men who can take this beautiful ship out of port with a crew of approximately 84.   He took us throughout the ship and shared such amazing details that only a knowing eye could share.   We never would have embraced the true history of this ship without his knowledge and attention to detail.   Thank you Peter for showing us the beauty of the USS constitution and thank you for your service.  You gave these two ladies from New York a memory they won’t soon forget !

A great attraction to take people from out of town. The staff was super helpful, and it was free to enter. I found some good postcards for my Navy dad. Great for families as well. Just be aware that the ceilings are a bit low and that there are some steep stairs.

Lovely historical museum. Important to our nations education, the amount of kids there warmed my heart.
The sailor led tour was educational and fun. If you happen to be there at sunset or sunrise you can watch them shoot the canon :)

YOU NEED TO GO THROUGH A METAL DETECTOR AND ADULTS NEED ID!!  The displays and ship were cool and the staff were friendly - except the security checkpoint people who were gruff.  I question the fiscal decision to keep this ship commissioned and have active duty military personnel working as tour people.  Their job could be handled well by National Park Service and lower cost.

This museum gives a comprehensive history of the warship Constitution which was built in 1797 and has been refurbished multiple times. It’s amazing to see the actual wooden ship which is over 200 years old. From here we walked about 20 minutes to Bunker Hill Monument.

Small, off the beaten path, but phenomenal museum collection containing many Oliver Wendell Holmes items along with a Beuchane skull, a great collection of porcelain apothecary jars, and many other medical items. The staff, even those in entirely unrelated departments within the same building were incredibly helpful.
It is in the Harvard Library. Top floor. Very small.

This place was smaller than I expected and a little difficult to get to. I would still highly recommend stopping in and viewing the exhibits, but don't make a trip out just for this museum. I would suggest pairing your visit with the Museum of Fine Arts (just one T stop away).

Fun to look at biological specimens that have featured so highly in biology, medical, and anatomical textbooks as well as non-fiction. As well as some that serves as the inspiration for great works of fiction as well.
The exhibits are unique and commendable. However it's more like a display case rather than a museum. I hope that they will be able to find a permanent museum to display the remaining exhibits.

I just wanted to say a thank you to Jason Landry at the Panopticon Gallery. I recently sold one of my prints, my very first ever through a gallery, at the recent NHIA Student Exhibition. Jason took care of everything and shipped the archival print (printed at Panopticon Imaging) to its new owner. Thanks for making this such a smooth and memorable experience for me.
Great work is always there, and the curator makes for good conversation.

"Lee Young Jun PEN ART"

Pen Art(General Remarks)

Infinity of lines and dots have symbolism.  Such symbolism is ever changing according to the spirit’s depth.  All works are kaleidoscopic; they are usually composed of indescribable expressions.  Therefore, art’s depth also can be said to be unlimited.  Is pen art’s depth also infinite?  In other words, do the lines and dots flowing from the nib of a pen have an artistic qualification?  In this respect, it is worth thinking deeply.  Pen art begins from an essence of nature’s fundamental values.  From the standpoint of value, or color, a harmony of black and white is essential in nature.  As it is impossible to see any color in darkness, distinguishing color is an essential role of light.  That is why the soul is drawn to light.  Whiteness, or light is a spiritual reflection of the soul while blackness, or darkness is a reality of life on earth.  As the color green is an essential color of vegetation, burnt charcoal is an earthy color that will stay near black.  Blackness is heterogeneous and may be hostile to life.  If blackness belongs to the essence of nature, it also may be said to represent the image of death.  A combination of black and white constitutes degrees of lightness and darkness.  When painting black on a white background, the soul is transported to the white background.  Whiteness comes to life when contrasted with black line and black space.  In this case, soul also may be expressed through the blackness.  Soul may be transported to the black or a combination of white and black, which shed a mysterious merit to the soul or spirit.  Pen arts starts and ends from an essence of nature’s fundamental contrasts.  The primary essence is infinite and eternal while the artistic harmony of black and white can take one’s breath away.  But, this is not possible until a metamorphosis has been realized over many years and spiritual transcendence has occurred.  The transfer of spirit  occurs when one’s life experiences are projected onto the white canvas in harmony with blackness.  That is the true ‘pen art.’               Artist  Lee Young Jun

I am a Korean. 
I pioneered the " Lee Young Jun Pen Art " and
Perfected the genre. 
I am Artist Lee Young Jun. 
Pen Art is the only genre is an important work In the world. 
The works are extremely valuable. 
And no one is able to work not dare to imitate. 
The hope my work can be sympathy to many people. Thank you.

"Lee  young jun PEN ART 총론"

(총론 :總論)PEN ART(Korea)
-------------------------------------------
선과 점의 무한함은 상징성이 있다.

그 상징성은 정신의 깊이에 따라 변화무쌍(變化無雙)하다.

모든 작품이 그러하다.

변화무쌍하기 때문에 형언할 수 없는 표현으로 이어진다.

그리하여 예술의 깊이는 무한한 것이다.

펜의 예술이라고 하면 깊이가 무한함이 있을까?

일반적으로 펜의 끝에서 흘러나오는 선과 점이 

과연, 예술성을 갖출 수 있겠는가 라는 점이다.

이점에 대하여 깊이 생각할 필요가 있다.

펜의 예술은 자연의 근본적인 색채의 본질에서부터 시작한다.

색채의 본질에서 보면 흑(黑), 백(白)의 조화는 자연의 근본적(根本的)이다.

조명이 없는 어두운 곳에서는 색을 볼 수 없듯이

색을 구분할 수 있게 해주는 것이 빛의 본질적인 작용이다.

때문에 흰색으로 나타나는 빛 속에서 영(靈)을 이끌어 들인다.

흰색 또는 빛은 영(靈)의 혼적(魂的)인 영상이다.

자연색은 검은 색이다. 녹색이 식물의 본질적인 색채인 것처럼

타버린 숯은 검은색으로 남는 본질적인 색상이다.

절대적인 어둠 속에서 어떤 생명의 운동도 있을 수 없다.

검은색은 생명에 대한 이질적(異質的)이고 적대성 (敵對性)이 있다.

검은색이 자연의 본질(本質)이라면, 검은색은 죽음의 영적(靈的)인 영상이다.

흰색이 검은색과 결합(結合)할 때 명암(明暗)이 이뤄진다. 

흰 화면에 검은색을 칠하면 靈이 흰 화면에 이입(移入)된다.

검은 선(線), 검은 면(面)과 만날 때, 흰색은 부활(復活)한다.

검은 색을 통하여 영을 표현할 수 있다.

영(靈)이란 검은색 속에 이입될 수 있는 유일한 것이며, 영과 혼의 색채 흑(黑), 백(白)을

결합(結合)하면 신비함을 갖는다. 그리고 펜의 예술은 자연의 근본적인 색채의 본질

에서부터 시작하여 근본적인 색채의 본질에서 끝을 맺는다.

근본적인 본질은 무한(無限)하고 영원함이 있으며, 흑, 백의 조화는 예술적(藝術的)으로

충분히 살아 숨쉴 수 있다. 그것은 오랜 시간을 통하여 다듬고 완성된 경지를 

이룬 뒤에야 가능하고, 혼(魂)을 담는 완벽한 선율이 전제 되어야 한다.

흑, 백의 조화 속에 고고(孤高)하고 생생한 선율이 흰 화면에 영이 이입될 때 비로소 영의 세계는 창조(創造)된다. 

그것이 진정한 펜의 예술이다.

                              이영준( 李  永 俊)

Food ...great. Atmosphere ...great. Being accosted by someone who is not your server on the way you tip is rude. Total tip for the table was over 15%. I was asked for more money by another server, as she stated, 'we live off this money.' She didn't care that it was our last day in Boston and my friend was covering the majority of the tip. I'll never be bullied for money again, because I'm not coming back to this restaurant.

Everyone is so nice and the food is amazing, very worth the price. it's not even that expensive it's just a bit more than you would expect. one of the cooks is really beautiful shes Brazilian and I have a crush :/

I visit Boston almost every month for business and work. This place is probably my favorite place to eat breakfast! You won't find anything special other than regular "American western" breakfast but the vibe is amazing, staff is very welcoming, overall fair price to. Careful on Sundays... HUGE line...

Upon walking in, we were able to grab a booth with no problem, though it quickly filled soon after. Service was great and I liked the atmosphere. They make your food quick but it doesn’t miss on the taste! I’ll definitely return

Very friendly service, they were also pretty quick!

The Texas burger was delicious, and very filling. 
I'm going to have to come back and try their cinnamon apple pancakes, they looked very tempting in the menu.

Lots of awesome food kiosks here. Of course since you are in Boston there are a lot of seafood based options. I have tried multiple different lobster rolls at different locations. Keep in mind, most of the cold or chilled lobster rolls are lobster salad. So if you want big chunks of lobster go for one that is either hot or butter poached. Although I can't remember the name, I also had a delicious piece of chicken wrapped in bacon at one of the kiosks. If you're hungry and don't know what to get this is a great place to start. Let your nose lead the way!

We had a great time we're pleasantly surprised about the area and the restaurants in the marketplace were amazing!! We spent an hour and a half there paid $40 for parking that was the only downfall. Was told by the very nice attendant on the way out of the parking garage that if we downloaded the app our fee would have been half price. Wish I could remember the name of the app worth investigating!

I love Faneuil Hall. It's great when the weather is nice and you have a group of people who all like different foods. The atmosphere is lively and welcoming. There's usually a performance of some sort happening. Lots of stores and lots of food choices. Usually difficult to find seating, but if the weather is nice you can sit anywhere.

This is a wonderful place to stop by for the history. The second and third floors (accessible by a staircase outside) are very interesting and provide several exhibits to look at. The lower floor has a couple of tourist shops and a printing press. Definitely go when all the floors are open (I believe that the museum on the third floor closes at three on weekdays), as the shops only take a few minutes to browse. There is also plenty of shops outside and around the market and it is within walking distance of downtown Boston.

Great place. First time I've been here and there was a lot to eat like seafood, BBQ & ice cream to name a few. On the sides of the food court there are small carts that sell a variety of items as mementos or presents. Will be coming back again for another tour for food. 🤤

Boston College has been a huge disappointment. Don't like the rankings fool you, this school is not worth your $70K a year. The only quality school with in Boston College is the business school, while the others lack any real merit. Being a student in both the school of arts & sciences, as well as the school of education, I have experience first hand how both of these schools lack proper faculty and class offerings. The advising system is horrible, I know too many people who have followed the advice of their advisors, who are meant to be trusted and be reliable sources of information, who have ended up in many class that do not count towards their major or graduation requirements. The class offerings are limited, even the elective offerings are great disappointments. I have many friends who are communications majors who's only elective offerings are courses related to gender. There are no offerings of classes that would be useful in the real world such as classes on public relations, advertising, event management, etc. In  communication writing intensives students are to write a 25 page paper. In one class taught by Brett Ingram, he told the students he would only be reading the first 10 pages of their paper because he could not be bothered to read the entire thing. He should not be teaching a writing intensive if he can't be bothered to give his students the respect of reading the full paper. I wish I had positive things to say, but I hope future potential students read this and think twice before attending BC.

Wonderful campus!!! It is really enormous and still accessible by car, or train very easily. At the entrance, there is a catholic church and beyond, a stadium is located. Each of the schools fosters values and quality research.
Beautiful campus with lots of stairs!

Despite having met some extraordinary professors, B.C. gets only one star because of its incompetent and dishonest administration.

I wish Yelp would allow for only one star.

I was accepted into a doctoral program at B.C. and completed 45 postgraduate credits at great cost financially and personally...tolerating late afternoon traffic on route 128 deserves recognition in itself.   My grades were all A or A- with a couple of B+ grades.

All was well....I was doing research for my dissertation and working full-time, when my parents were hit head-on by a trailer truck.   The good news is that their horrible injuries healed and with time and physical therapy they resumed a normal life.

When I asked B.C.'s administration for a 1-year extension on my dissertation (at the time they allowed only 2 years), they refused.  So I graduated with high honor with a C.A.E.S. (which requires only 30 credits, thus wasting 15 credits expensive in time, work, and money) and they named me to Phi Delta Kappa.

But no Ph.D.

It gets better.....

Two weeks before graduation, the dean's perfectly disgraceful secretary sent me a letter saying I could not graduate because I was never accepted!!

Fortunately, I had kept a copy of my acceptance letter and graduated.

When I wrote recently to inquire about an honorary doctorate for my lifetime career work I was ignored.

Just down the street there are better colleges and universities....B.U. and Northeastern are two much better choices....do not make the mistake I made in attending B.C.

Boston College has been a huge disappointment. Don't like the rankings fool you, this school is not worth your $70K a year. The only quality school with in Boston College is the business school, while the others lack any real merit. Being a student in both the school of arts & sciences, as well as the school of education, I have experience first hand how both of these schools lack proper faculty and class offerings. The advising system is horrible, I know too many people who have followed the advice of their advisors, who are meant to be trusted and be reliable sources of information, who have ended up in many class that do not count towards their major or graduation requirements. The class offerings are limited, even the elective offerings are great disappointments. I have many friends who are communications majors who's only elective offerings are courses related to gender. There are no offerings of classes that would be useful in the real world such as classes on public relations, advertising, event management, etc. In  communication writing intensives students are to write a 25 page paper. In one class taught by Brett Ingram, he told the students he would only be reading the first 10 pages of their paper because he could not be bothered to read the entire thing. He should not be teaching a writing intensive if he can't be bothered to give his students the respect of reading the full paper. I wish I had positive things to say, but I hope future potential students read this and think twice before attending BC.

Wonderful campus!!! It is really enormous and still accessible by car, or train very easily. At the entrance, there is a catholic church and beyond, a stadium is located. Each of the schools fosters values and quality research.
Beautiful campus with lots of stairs!

I have four university degrees, including a doctorate. I graduated from four different institutions in the U.S and overseas.  Northeastern U. is one  my most memorable and rewarding experiences of all. The professors are phenomenal. The student engagement activities, campus, and other learning environments are incredible.
Meeeeeeeeh it's ok..

I love Angora! The staff are very nice and welcoming. It's a great place to studying or just hanging out. Plus, the food is very good. Try the chocolate cookie with chocolate filling---unbelievable good.
The food is so tasty, fresh and cooked to order. The staff are so nice and always helpful, musician c is great too. Perfect for a quick meal or long hangout to study or get work done
Great place to stop for smoothies. The Noodle dish I had was pretty tasty too. It's a little bit pricey overall, but not outrageous.
Great place for a quick bite. Sadly looks like it’s closing soon. For lease signs are up
Hands down... my favorite fro-yo/ice cream! Rasberry and brownie bits... every single time. I'd drive an hour for the ice cream.

A great breakfast place in the neighborhood! Can't go wrong with their breakfast sandwiches. Definitely recommend going on the weekdays as the line on the weekend is just ridiculous. Which I guess is a good sign but as good as the food is, is it worth a 40+ minute wait?

Awesome breakfast spot! Tends to have a line on the weekends but it moves pretty fast. Parking in the back is handy. Food is delicious and plentiful. I recommend the detention (steak and eggs) and french toast to share for dessert. Kid friendly as well, our kids loved the shakes (though they are huge and should be shared)

solid breakfast/brunch place. Haven't been for lunch but I'm a huge breakfast guy. Steak tips (rare-medrare of course) super tender and flavorful, fresh squeezed a little pricey but delicious. great service from the people

The Breakfast Club was excellent - dined with a group of 4 and sat at the counter. Bit of a line (which can and often extends outdoors - bring your umbrella on a rainy day) but worth the wait, be sure to speak up when they ask who is next. Aside from the great/fresh food and reasonable prices our experience was really elevated because of the cook Paul. Paul interacted with the group in a memorable and unique way that will ensure we return. Be sure to order one of their milk shakes.  This place is the quintessential All American Diner. We love you Paul!
Great food, solid 80's atmosphere. Friendly and attractive staff. Enjoy going here. There can be a bit of a wait so plan ahead if your out during colder months, as the wait is usually outside.

AMAZING!!! My family of 4 came in at a busy time on a Sunday and the owner of the resturant made sure we had a good place to sit. He even personally checked on us during our meal. The menu is extensive, lots to choose from, and everything is delicious! Check them out ASAP!

The guys who run this place are some of the kindest people I know. They always go out of their way to make me exactly what I want and in a timely manner. Great, simple salads and sandwiches. Always a great spot for any meal.
It was great. Solid food. Fair pricing. Clean dining room. Great staff. Fast (even though it was really busy). Exactly what you should expect. Parking is a little touchy, but that's not their fault.
The burgers here are amazing! They're probably among the best in Boston. If you're in the area, definitely check this place out.
Great for a quick, local bite! Big fan of their breakfast options, but also have to recommend their french fries!
One of my favorite froyo shops..be cautious it's easy to spend $15
I've been going here for years and the taro froyo gives purpose to my life, it never lets me down.

They charge more than 50 cents per ounce which is pretty pricey.
All the flavours taste similar. Their plain yogurt is way too sweet for my taste.
However, they have a wide variety of toppings to choose from and the fruits are fresh!
Good froyo, pay by the weight.  Pretty standard stuff. Their tart flavors are great.

Super friendly staff. Served us a sample of each one we askes for. Limited flavors but all were really good. The Original Tart and Watermelon Sorbet were my girfriends favorite. I went with cookies'n Cream and caramel. They had more toppings than I could have even thought of. Really good experience for us.

I happen to be a wicked famous person here in Boston.  I like Spikes. I was there when it opened. I eat the junk yard dogs. Chili fries are good too.  The place is like wicked clean too.  They got their own root beer and stuff. Five stars mates

I used to stop here as a young twenty something after the bars. Always loved the staff, atmosphere and most of all the dogs. Menu is more than hot dogs but with so many custom dogs on the menu I don't think I ever tried anything else.  I have since moved away and grown older...... today while in town I could not resist a junkyard dog. Went with my favorite the Texas ranger dog with fries. It did not disappoint.  Even after all these years and hyped expectations it tasted so good,still my favorite dog. Ps the Fries are good to. Thanks Dave!
Great local hotdogs, burgers and chicken shop. Fresh, tasty icon of Boston’s best. Driving by and stopped. Dave’s a personal friendly owner.
Spike s is my favorite place for gourmet hot dogs and chili fries.  I am like a wicked pissa famous person in Boston so I know where to go. Super friendly service and wicked clean too
Great customer service. And amazing cookies. Decent food
Very delicious food- full of flavor and very filling. Wish they had samosa soup (like other Burmese restaurants I have been to) but definitely recommend the place.
It's pretty good Burmese food and (in my opinion) not unauthentic! I tried a few dishes here and I'll definitely be back to try more. I really appreciate that I can buy fermented tea leaves here.

This restaurant was very good. My husband and I went here to celebrate our anniversary. We have tried from Burmese food once in San Francisco and it was hard for us to find a place in Boston or near Boston that served Burmese food. So when we found this place we were really happy and decided to try it. We were not disappointed. The food was delicious and fresh. I ordered the tea salad which is quite a popular Burmese dish. It was exactly as I remembered. The vegetables were fresh and there was a variety of toppings. My husband ordered a dish called the Shang noodles and he said it was delicious. The servings were generous and everything came out at a reasonable paste. Also I tried their yogurt drink which was so amazing. The prices were very good and we were very satisfied with the service. The restaurant atmosphere was nice and cozy and it was very clean. I highly recommend this restaurant.

They are rather over priced for what they offer. Taste is mediocre too. They try to put in effort, but somehow doesn't translate, very mom-pop, needs better business acumen. The heavy student population of the area probably keeps them up, else would have been hard to survive. I still believe it has potential, but needs to seriously revive. At least quality and portions can improve...of the topping meat or shrimp, especially for the price.
Try the tea salad. It's really different and good!

Great place for take out sushi. I used to order lunch from time to time (usually the sashimi or two-roll lunch meal). Everything was always fresh, well portioned, and delicious. I know some people who gave reviews were expecting Oya level sushi, however, this isn't that type of place. It is a great place for a quick meal of fresh sushi that will satisfy your craving without burning your wallet.
This is my family's go-to place for sushi. Excellent food in a tiny space (we usually do take-out).
High-quality yet reasonably priced (for sushi) with extremely helpful kind service. The sushi is an explosion of flavor in your mouth no matter what you order. My definitely go-to place for sushi.
Quality fresh sushi and nigiri, well prepared, sizable portions, intimate settings, fast and friendly service.  Excellent choice for dinner.
Really long dishes of delicious sushi. You better be hungry or ready to share.

My entire family went here on a balmy July night and we were treated with exceptional attention and service. All ten of us enjoyed our meals, with everyone having ordered something different. What's more, there isn't a wine menu, but instead you get to go choose your bottles from a wine rack of a selection hand-picked by the owner that day. Overall a great experience.
The experience was really good and unexpected. Both vegetarian and meat were good.
Some very nice dishes and a wonderful staff!

I can't believe it's possible to get healthy food while traveling! And at a reasonable price. In a town where everything is so expensive and of questionable quality, this place is an outstanding exception. Sadly it's also easy to see why so much of America is overweight and diabetic- - I've been here 20 minutes enjoying an outstanding breakfast, and I've been the only customer. This place should be flooded. But for those who know the value of healthy food, this is the place to go.

B good is always as the name says: Good!  The food is simple in the best of ways:  you can taste all of the ingredients, which are locally sourced and most of the time fresh.  I love the fries as well as the drinks.

I'm somewhat surprised at the number of positive reviews for the B. Good burger.  

The bun it came on was surprisingly good, though somewhat earthy in flavor, with more chew than your typical commercial burger bun.  While the bun/patty ratio seems good, the fact that the bun doesn't squish the way that a typical commercial bun would, means that eating the burger is rather messy.  Yes, the burger comes wrapped in paper, but because the burger itself is rather small and dense, the wrapping does less to keep one's hands clean than to get in one's way while trying to eat it.

I ordered the mushroom Swiss burger, which was tasty enough, though the mushrooms were cold.  And I mean, straight-out-of-the-refrigerator cold, which was an unpleasant contrast to the warm bun, hot patty, sauteed onions, and melted Swiss.  Yes, the burger tasted somewhat more "fresh" and homemade than other fast food burgers, but then, that's not really what a fast food burger is about.

Anyway, this place caters to a crowd that wants to feel that they are eating healthy/healthier options and I think B. Good delivers on that front.  However, to compare this place to Tasty Burger is just so, so, deeply incorrect.
Tell your employees to smile and greet customers. Be approachable and not looking as if you're an unhappy worker. Other than that, food was great!

A lot more of these type of healthy and locally sourced places have been opening up, and inn quite glad to see it.  But B.GOOD is probably my favorite of the bunch.  The smoothies are quite good and I quite enjoy the burgers, but when I want to be super health conscious I can eat some great vegetarian opening too.  It's worth experimenting with things like that to keep an open mind
Go to Herrera's once a week or so.  Love their food! Staff is friendly and very fast and efficient at making the food.  Lunch time can get very busy there!
They run out of vegetables at the end of the day
Less crowded. Food are for considerable price. Nice service.
Really solid Chinese food at reasonable prices. The people that run it are very nice and service has always been quick. I have been plaesed with both delivery and dining in.
Great quality/price. The lady seem quite rude at the beginning but she is very nice. Good food, good prices. Free tea and fortune cookie! Highly recommend for a shopping break!
This place is very quiet. Feels like a restaurant from Spirited Away movie.
A comfortable place to just go and eat comfort food. They have healthy options, but the menu items are not cheap, and majority of dishes are very oily.

Generous portions and flavorful food. Prices all around $8.88. Convenient location across from BU as well. Large amount of seating and quality foods for a one $ sign place. They have free hot tea and cold water that you get yourself. Totally worth coming here for a quality quick meal. Visited Boston and ate at this solid dining experience place. The best one $ sign you will find for Boston

I have had many meals at Nud Pob and can confirm that their food is delicious and their service is quick. It does get packed around lunchtime, so be mindful of that when going with a large group. $10 minimum charge for credit cards - if you need to purchase something to meet the minimum, I recommend the Gyoza!
Great food, the place requires some maintenance sticky floors and funky smells. But I'd definitely go again for the food. The curries are awesome!

The food was good but it is SO crowded in here at lunch time! Orders came out fast but it's hard to get a seat/have a conversation with everyone jostling around. I would get takeout next time. I like that they have pictures of the food on the menu on the wall. I enjoyed my spicy ground chicken over rice. They lean pretty hot so be aware.

Nud Pob is one of my favorite go to places for food. The Thai food there is superb and I love ordering the Thai pad thai and the Indonesian fried rice. Their pad see you is also very very good. I love this place because it is a nice place to just sit and enjoy your food with complimentary hot tea and water that you can self serve. And I always have extra food to bring home because I can never finish it!

AMAZING EXPERIENCE! All the staff from the door man to our server and bartender were awesome! Our food was spectacular, fast, and delicious. The service was super fast and friendly. This was all on the day of the Super Bowl parade so it was insanely busy and still everything was great. Thanks for a wonderful experience.

Best bar in Boston, if you like a pub feel! The staff here are delightful and outrageously accommodating, and the food discounts on Wednesday, Thursday, and Saturday genuinely made my jaw drop. Everything here is somehow cheaper than at normal Boston bars, but equally as tasty.

Best place in Boston for a cheap and quick burguer/beer combo! Lots of college crowd as well as old timers as myself. Happy environment, great place for watching sports! Breakfast served all day. Breakfast burger with over easy egg is a must have!
Great dive bar - food really great and cheap. Even had some salad selections! Beer was pricy ($7 for a standard Guinness) but glad I was here. Good breakfast as well. Bathroom was a little gross.
Always an awesome breakfast for not a lot of money. Friendly service. Definitely a go to

Small little Japanese & Chinese restaurant located on Boston St. The server was great. He kept up with a nearly full restaurant by himself without skipping a beat. The salmon sashimi was Delicious. It was very tasteful and was obviously very fresh. All the food and sushi we ordered was on point. Everything was reasonably priced
Awesome food. I've been going to this place since I was a teenager. This location has friendly staff and prompt service.

I could eat here for the rest of my life. The spicy chicken bowl with lo mein is heaven when you have a hang over. People complain about delivery but all you need to do is COMMUNICATE. They come to my house so often they call me to come down before they even pull up. Order wrong just give them a call and they will accommodate you. Faster delivery include the tip on the card and you can grab your food and go. Need faster pick up use grubhub. Bubble tea is yummy. Smoothies are filling. Location is small but lively.
Pleasantly surprised..  ordered food to meet the order minimum and it ended up being super solid! I originally ordered for the boba but I’ll order again for both.

These people are sooooooooooooo rude   They act like we owe them something when im the paying customer   Never again will u ever get my $$$$ again. Maybe you should take some customer appreciation classes.

A MUST if you are in Boston! My boyfriend and I visited Grill 23 & Bar after waiting for 30 minutes at another restaurant to have our order taken (with reservations). After our experience, we wished we would have come here first instead! We walked in starving and hoping to get a table. Matt greeted us with open arms and showed us the most wonderful time. The service: phenomenal. The food: out of this world. My boyfriend ordered the Filet which was seared wonderfully and tasted amazing. I ordered the pork chop which was one of the best dishes I’ve ever had. 
Thank you so much to the staff of Grill 23 & Bar for turning a frustrating evening into one for the books! And a special thanks to Matt for your hospitality and wonderful service!
A great place to enjoy a delicious meal! The food and service were truly fantastic. Will be coming back on our next venture to Boston! Would recommend the pork chop, it’s was wonderful!

Had dinner here and it was an excellent experience. Prices are high, but for a special night out, it is worth it. Service was stellar. Shared sides were enough for all, and the steaks were wonderful. Friends also enjoyed the salmon, tuna and chicken. Bread pudding was also excellent!

Absolutely fantastic. Excellent selection on all accounts. Best part?!? Our waiter didn't ask me how everything was with my mouth full. He didn't even ask how it was at all. He knew it was 200% delicious. I thanked him for having done so and he laughed. Had a great time will def go back and recommend to friends.
We got the veal chop, the 100 day aged steak, mushrooms, and asparagus. Cooked to perfection! Service was excellent.

Top of the Hub was the absolute most anticipated and best dining experience during our time in Boston.  I highly recommend visiting this fantastic establishment.  Our seating arrangement was such that we could see a large portion of the downtown Boston. We chose a 4 course meal with wine parings with each course.  The cost was very reasonable and totally worth the experience.  As I write this review almost a year later, I can still remember the exquisite main course and wine pairings.

Great service and good ambiance. Lamp chop is very tender and well seasoned with the red wine sauce. Side dishes are good too. 

We ordered the lobster bisque, also very delicious.

The only bad thing is bad ventilation in women’s restroom.   Quite uncomfortable.

Great ambiance and scenery.
Service average. Reception was not.welcoming. Waiting was mediocre.

What a gem this place is. We decided to go to this place, which was a pretty good choice.
It's got some delicious food.

The food is incredible. The servers anticipated our needs very well.

AMAZING EXPERIENCE! All the staff from the door man to our server and bartender were awesome! Our food was spectacular, fast, and delicious. The service was super fast and friendly. Best bar in Boston, if you like a pub feel! The staff here are delightful and outrageously accommodating, and the food discounts on Wednesday, Thursday, and Saturday genuinely made my jaw drop. Everything here is somehow cheaper than at normal Boston bars, but equally as tasty.

Best place in Boston for a cheap and quick burguer/beer combo! Lots of college crowd as well as old timers as myself. Happy environment, great place for watching sports! Breakfast served all day. Breakfast burger with over easy egg is a must have!
Great dive bar - food really great and cheap. Even had some salad selections! Beer was pricy ($7 for a standard Guinness) but glad I was here. Good breakfast as well. Bathroom was a little gross.
Always an awesome breakfast for not a lot of money. Friendly service. Definitely a go to

Great PIZZA. Very nice dough.  Lovely cozy place- good atmosphere and even better service. Limited seating. I would highly recommend trying to make a reservation. Or grab some pizza to go! The takeout was non-stop while we were there and I can definitely see why

This is my new (I know, I’m late to the game) favorite spot in Boston. Tiny, cozy, and amazing food. Perfect for date night and also super family friendly. If you’re looking for classy, quality, Italian pizza.. this is it. And if you wanna go cheap, you could honestly spend $25 + tip for a dinner for 2. The pizzas are big.
Delicious food, remarkable service, fantastic ambiance. Always impressed when I come here. Great spot for a date night or to catch up with an old friend.
Can’t say I loved the food. Chicken Parmigiana was too complicated. Personally I prefer the Italian classics. Meatballs were very good though.
Reliably excellent pizzas in an intimate setting. They serve other dishes as well, but I always go for the pizza.

My ship was here back in 1973 USS McCloy, now I think is a Mexican ship. DE 1038 in 1973. It's nice that breed's hill (bunker hill is close by) and also the subway is very close. And the USS constitution (old ironsides). I was only stationed here for a couple of months but it was a pretty good time overall. I was real young and stupid though I did manage to survive somehow. (I was only 18 at the time). Met some interesting folks on my ship also.

Great place to visit (with or without kids).   Museum of free, with suggested donation.  It has a number of informative sections and interactive learning portions for kids.  The whole second floor is really dedicated for children from 5-12. Clean facilities and the USS Constitution is something to behold.  You will need to pass through a checkpoint (screening) to get on board the ship.  Plenty of photo opportunities. I've been twice, today being the 2nd time.  I'd go back again in a few years for sure.
Historical, well managed, informative and fun. Get your National Park Passport stamped here!

The Charleston Navy Yard is an important historical port in America, having operated from 1800 and 1974. Here visitors can walk the grounds of the shipyard, see the dry docks and enjoy important attractions during their visits to Boston. 

The Charleston Navy Yard visitor centre is open from 9-5pm. You clear security here for tours of the historic USS Constitution warship. There is useful information and displays regarding the The vessel at the visitor centre as well as a gift shop if interested to by a souvenir. 

You will find an even better USS Constitution Museum further down the navy yard. It is very much worth spending some time at the is family-friendly museum before or after touring the historic vessel. 

At the Navy Yard, you can also board the Fletcher class destroyer, USS Cassin Young, which is docked here. This ship saw action in the Pacific during WWII and is available for self-guided touring. Another nice attraction to look out for is the early 19th century Commandant's House perched on a hill just above the navy yard. 

Some of the key buildings and machinery around the navy yard have been left for you to see and there are plenty of information signs throughout. These are very helpful if you are unfamiliar with shipyards. 

Overall, we enjoyed our stop at the Charlestown Navy Yard, finding this a nice place to spend a couple hours as part of our visit of the Boston Freedom Trail. This is a neat place for anyone with interest in sea vessels, maritime, military and/or early American history. 

Note: The USS Constitution vessel has irregular visitation days and hours so do make sure to check their online website for updated openings prior to planning your visit.

This involves visiting the actual USS Constitution and USS Cassin Young. You will need to show a photo ID or passport (adults only) and go through security to enter the visitor center and go on the ships. The ships are a self guided tour. Very cool! I suggest watching the short movie when you arrive in the visitor center to give you a historical background of the Navy Yard.
Take a gander at the dates on these revolutionary era tombstones. A little creepy at night.
Great AS meetings on Mondays so I hear
St John’s is the definition of what Episcopal church is all about. This place is about love.
Love this church

Amazing place. After you pass all the freedom trail, and you don't have a lot of power. This squar has a lot of grass where you can lay there. And some benches. I really like this park. Really really suggested!!!
A Place I Can Relax And Reflect , Present Day , Past , And My Future ...
It's a nice place to stop and relax on your way to or from bunker hill. Very clean. Mostly quiet. And very pretty little neighborhood park.
It's a square!
Peaceful place and nice people out and about.

Tried the vegetable couscous and that was pretty good. The hookah however was okay at best and at $40 for a basic hookah that's not okay... They even count the number of pieces of coal you use so they can charge you for extra coals after 2 coal refreshes... Even though the hookah is $40... Extremely overpriced

Always a great time at Tangierinos. The food was excellent as always, and the ambience is like no other place in Boston. The lounge is also a must for any cigar and hookah aficionado! Perfect place for celebrating special occasions or just hanging out amongst friends!
Place has awesome food with great entertainment. Staff is amazing and very helpful. Parking is tough but they have valet. A lot of items are extremely over priced in my opinion
Always a great time. Excellent service and atmosphere. People from all over visit because of the experience.
Amazing Moroccan food!! Great service. Fun belly dancers!! A fabulous spot for dinner!!

What a great local spot that’s perfect to bring kids. It’s very family friendly and a fun environment.  Plus most importantly the pizza is awesome. There’s a ton of good options if you don’t want pizza. And the beer selection is great. Definitely worth checking out

Service is always great . Bartenders are helpful and knowledgeable about the beer.   Beer and wine selection is always impressive. Pizza is always cooked to perfection and is some of the best in the area. Crust is flavorfully delicious and has a perfect chew. Toppings are always fresh. Killer bee is truly killer!
Great beer selection, awesome wood-fire pizzas, and super-friendly service from the wait staff. Would highly recommend to those wanting to venute outside downtown Boston.

Good selection of beer and food. Staff was extremely friendly. We ate here in the afternoon with a 5 month old. They have a changing table in the restroom. Would recommend as a place to stop in for lunch if you're in need of a friendly spot to refuel with a sandwich and a drink.
The food was phenomenal. It was better than I expected it to be. Nice friendly environment.
Waitress was friendly. She came around to maintain our drinks. Most of all, there food is fantastic.
Food is absolutely amazing ! You have to try!!!  And the staff are so sweet !
Very cozy, and kind of diner styled. Very good food at a reasonable price, with very sweet attentive staff who keep a smile! I highly recommend Grasshopper cafe to anyone in the area!!

Sometimes you accidentally find a gem of a place and it makes your day better.  That happened to us. We were just looking for a little breakfast before a day of sight--seeing in Boston.  The Grasshopper Cafe is that kind of place.The coffee was special and everything was cooked perfectly. If you're looking for an "off the beaten path" breakfast close to Bunker Hill or the Constitution please try this spot.

I want to love it, or even like it. But after years of disappointing meals, I’m done. Everything is just blah, and my expectations for breakfast food are appropriately measured - simply holding this up to classic diner standards. The coffee is especially horrid. However, the staff seem to be uniformly efficient and nice. So if you absolutely need a plate of eggs and bacon and can’t bring yourself to walk to Bacon Truck or drive to Buddy’s Diner, go here and tip well. But the food (and for the love of God, the coffee) could use a major revamp.

Fabulous sandwich! Love that they have the option for extra meat or veggies. Bread was crunchy and soft at the same time and flavor was on point! Fresh Mango bubble tea hit the mark too. Service was super friendly. All around great experience.

The best vietnamese sandwich and $1 fried egg roll shop! Always get the mango shake ($3.50 w/o boba). They use fresh, real mangoes every time!

Cash only. Very nice and friendly ladies that works here. Understands English and speaks Chinese and Vietnamese
Good banh mi, but pricier and less meat compared to other banh mi places.
Nice service and great boba and sandwiches
Amazing pork bon mi.

Wandered into this place because it was open late and we were really hungry. The service was fabulous at 1am. We were really impressed. The food was delicious and we wished we had room in our bellies to try other foods. The Dungeness crab was cooked to perfection and the oysters were so juicy and flavorful.

Authentic Chinese food - they’re also open until late for after weekend festivities! I come here often for lunch and it’s not too bad around noon. Some of my coworkers have been coming for decades and the wait staff already knows their orders!
Great place for seafood.  Lobster was delicious.   Great service.

Terrible dining experience there last night. The waitress rushed the customers out as soon the the food is finished and demands hefty amount of tips. Disappointed by the google rating it’s supposed to be for.

Old establishment in need of an update badly. Mediocre food in an extremely cramped environment. If you enjoy eating poor quality food and getting the occasional elbow while eating, you will like it here. Otherwise, you have many better options just a few feet away. Also, keep in mind that it is in the basement.
They have the best egg tarts! All the pastries are delicious. I highly recommend you try 1 or more.

Eldo Cake House has the best cakes anywhere, period. The frosting is light and not overly sweet. The fruit on top is fresh and tasty. It's the only place my family will accept. The other Chinese baked goods are ok.
Yummy cakes! Nice, light and fluffy. My sugar momma brings them to me sometimes and I scarf them up like the cow that I am!

Cheap baked goods that are absolutely delicious! They have stuff like egg tarts and fruit cakes, the best of which is the mango mousse. It’s a good stop for breakfast as well, as they have steamed buns with meat and egg for only two dollars.

This place has the best sponge cakes you can find in Boston...I usually get either the strawberry or peach filling...The cake are delicious and have just enough sugar which are perfect for my family and friends...The only problem this place has is there is no parking whatsoever...I suggest having someone wait outside in the car while you place your order...

Friendly, clean, and VERY tasty!!  All the food is freshly made, tasty and hot.  It's a new addition to my list of favorite places to eat and hang out.  Thanks to Mary at MEEI for the recommendation!!!

Love it. First time i visited here was about 25 years ago. Delicious little nook that is well worth the find. Very competitive pricing and friendly staff make it a great time. Try their afternoon dim sum too. Just yummy.

I went there for a wedding, of which was fun. There was lots of food, some of us could not finish, but it kept on coming. It is very Asian based, but is still good. Eating there, and being not too used to some of the things, I didn't eat too much, but some things were good, and would recommend. If your into Asian food, and looking for a pretty good place to eat at, I'd say give it a try.

Great spot for dim sum! Pretty large space and we have never had to wait very long for a table. Chicken feet for those who are into that and delicious dumplings for those who might not be as adventurous as others.
Great food, service was good kinda hectic but was able to get in and out okay

Loved the Dim Sum experience. Strongly recommend going with someone who speaks the language because it is a bit of a barrier but still came away satisfied. Go with an open mind and hungry. Try even if you don't think you will like something because chances are it will become your new favorite. and definitely bring children and go up to the buffet bar before you become too full from passing carts. The stuffed eggplant, greens with oyster sauce and clams are at the buffet bar and those are seriously good eats.
Dim sum every day. Delicious. Great way to feed a group for very little. Easy to get to, lots of nearby parking, and, for some reason, Animal Planet on their big TV.

Really good dim sum. Everything is on carts just circling the tables and you select what you want, makes for a pretty neat environment. The dumplings are A1, and everything is kept properly hot and fresh if you're smart about what you order. Pretty reasonably priced for dim sum, parking can occasionally be a hassle if you go during a busy time
Very good dim sum! Friendly staff and tremendous variety.

I’ve sampled various Chinese fare throughout Boston and had a hunch that Chau Chow would be an exceptional delight.  I was NOT disappointed.  The assortment spans the familiar to the more lavish, with an emphasis on seafood (as it should).

My first order (and YES, there WILL be more) consisted of a very ordinary egg rolls (crisp and fresh), hot’n’sour soup (FINALLY!!!!), jumbo shrimp with cashew (enormous shrimp, filled with vegetables, if you like that sort of thing), and a BBQ pork fried rice (tasty and a generous portion).

I will caution that delivery is not an option, which in my case, involved a $25 round trip Uber; well worth the cost (in my case; less than parking).  Speaking of which, there is a modest parking lot, so if you’re driving, that shouldn’t be a challenge.  Easy to find, welcoming when you arrive.

Are you really still reading this and not dropping everything to order?

This is Chinese food as it should be.

Born appetit!!
My favorite Chinese place in the WORLD. I'm lucky if I go there once a year. Each time I leave happy.

Food is very good and the price is fair.  The venue used to be an old theater in the late 80s but later converted to a restaurant.  It is a little dated but the high ceiling, arches, and wall murals make it look pretty nice.  Its main room can hold 60 large tables.  Plenty of room.  One extra thing I like is that you don't get that typical Chinese restaurant smell on your hair or clothes after your visit.

Hands down FIVE STAR for this restaurant! My dad brings the family to Boston Chinatown for many man years, and we trust that this restaurant delivers only the BEST Cantonese dim sum and traditional food! The wait staff are very polite and friendly. They love to chat with us about life. The food is always delivered hot and fresh. They can make any Cantonese dim sum dish you ask. We are never disappointed with this restaurant, and we will continue to come here as long as they are open!

The most authentic Chinese restaurant that I know of in Boston... maybe all of New England. 

I grew up in a Chinese family in LA. Trips to Chinese markets and sketchy back alley food counters were pretty standard. Every now and then we would go to one of the fancy Chinese banquet halls for a family gathering or a wedding. That's what Empire Garden is. Amazing lo mein, tender Chinese broccoli, elegant dim sum - they've got some real standout dishes here. Everything that we've had is delicious. Even things that I hated as a kid were good here. A must try if you're looking for the real experience of a Chinese banquet hall!

Amazing.....we have never tasted better Chinese food. The hospitality was very friendly and tending. Our waiter made sure our experience was optimal. The price was on point, I would have even paid more for that delicious food. The structure is breathtaking. Wonderful. ..

Loved the Dim Sum experience. Strongly recommend going with someone who speaks the language because it is a bit of a barrier but still came away satisfied. Go with an open mind and hungry. Try even if you don't think you will like something because chances are it will become your new favorite. and definitely bring children and go up to the buffet bar before you become too full from passing carts. The stuffed eggplant, greens with oyster sauce and clams are at the buffet bar and those are seriously good eats.
Dim sum every day. Delicious. Great way to feed a group for very little. Easy to get to, lots of nearby parking, and, for some reason, Animal Planet on their big TV.

Really good dim sum. Everything is on carts just circling the tables and you select what you want, makes for a pretty neat environment. The dumplings are A1, and everything is kept properly hot and fresh if you're smart about what you order. Pretty reasonably priced for dim sum, parking can occasionally be a hassle if you go during a busy time
Very good dim sum! Friendly staff and tremendous variety.
